III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Wolverine Center staff did not provide for the needs, protection,
and supervision of Youth A when he was able to truant multiple
times in May 2023.
Investigation Complainant
I spoke with Complainant on 06/06/2023 by phone. Complainant is
a hospital worker, who is concerned with the frequency of Youth
A’s truancies and his ability to obtain alcohol and drugs while
truant from Wolverine Center. Complainant stated Youth A said he
had “things to do, people to see” as his reason to truant. I told
Complainant that I would review staff supervision in relation to
Youth A’s truancy form Wolverine Center. I also explained to
Complainant that Wolverine Center is an open program. This
requires exit doors open in one continuous motion and maintained
in an unobstructed manner.
Youth A
Youth A was placed at Wolverine Center on 03/28/2023. Youth A
was unavailable for an interview on 06/05/2023 due to being
truant. Youth A was unavailable for an interview from 06/08/2023
to 06/14/2023 while he visited his grandmother, who came up
from Florida. Wolverine Center held Youth A’s bed open during his
visit with his grandmother, but Youth A was replaced directly from
his visit with his grandmother to a foster home on 06/14/2023.
Foster care worker requested on 06/23/2023 that Youth A not be
interviewed to prevent triggering him and disrupting his current
placement.
Youth A’s foster care worker
I spoke with Youth A’s Foster care worker (FCW) on 06/06/2023
and 06/09/2023 by phone. FCW stated she checks in with Youth A
twice a week by phone. FCW stated Youth A has petitions filed
and she is working on placing Youth A in a secure and permanent
placement. FCW stated Wolverine Center went above and beyond
2

and continues to do so in working with Youth A and his frequent
truancies.
I spoke with Youth A’s FCW on 06/23/2023 by phone. FCW stated
Youth A’s petitions were dismissed. FCW stated Youth A is
adjusting and doing well in his foster home placement. FCW
reiterated Wolverine Center went above and beyond working with
Youth A by encouraging him to stay at the facility, asking him what
he needed to remain at the facility, shadowing him, and reporting
his truant location when known to attempt to redirect him to return
to the facility.
Incident reports
I reviewed Youth A’s truancy incident reports from 05/2023 to
present. Required parties were notified for each truancy.
• 05/09/2023 Youth A truanted at 8:20 pm from facility after
returning from an outing. Staff followed Youth A in a vehicle
and located Youth A at a store. Youth A ran from the store.
• 05/10/2023 Youth A truanted at 7:15 pm when it was time
to enter the facility for medication dispensing. Staff followed
Youth A in a vehicle and spotted him. Law enforcement
approached Youth A and Youth A ran.
• 05/13/2023 Youth A truanted at 8:40 pm from the facility.
Staff followed Youth A. Youth A refused to return.
• 05/14/2023 Youth A truanted at 1:15 pm from the facility
parking lot. Staff followed Youth A. Youth A returned to the
facility with staff.
• 05/14/2023 Youth A truanted at 4:40 pm from the
basketball court. Staff followed Youth A until he went into
an abandoned house.
• 05/14/2023 Youth A truanted at 10:45 pm from the facility.
Staff followed Youth A until line of sight was lost. Youth A
was later seen at a gas station and driven back to the
facility by staff.
• 05/15/2023 Youth A truanted at 5:45 pm when he refused
to enter the facility. Staff followed him until line of sight was
lost.
• 05/17/2023 Youth A truanted at 9:30 am when he ran out
the door from the facility. Staff ran after Youth A and he
refused to return. Youth A headed towards the park.
• 05/19/2023 Youth A truanted at 1:00 pm from the facility
playscape. Staff followed Youth A. Youth A refused to
return.
• 05/19/2023 Youth A truanted at 4:50 pm when he ran out of
the gym at the facility. Staff followed Youth A. Youth A
refused to return.

4

Administrator 1
I spoke with Administrator 1 on 06/05/2023 by phone.
Administrator 1 stated Youth A frequently truants from Wolverine
Center and is not taking his medication. Administrator 1 stated he
and his staff follow Youth A on his truancies until line of sight is
lost. Administrator 1 stated off duty staff have seen Youth A at
local gas stations and stores and reported Youth A’s whereabouts
for staff to locate and attempt to redirect Youth A back to the
facility. Administrator 1 stated Youth A is taken for a medical
evaluation upon his return from truancy when it appears he is
under the influence. Administrator 1 stated working with Youth A’s
FCW on securing appropriate placement for Youth A.
Analysis Youth A truanted 27 times from 05/09/2023 to 06/08/2023. Each
time staff were aware of the truancy and followed Youth A until
Youth A returned to the facility or line of sight was lost. Wolverine
Center is an open program, which requires exit doors open in one
continuous motion and maintained in an unobstructed manner.
Youth A’s truancy pattern is alarming and what happens during his
truancy time is unknown, but Wolverine Center provided the
needs, protection, and supervision of Youth A when he was at the
facility.
CONSULTATION
Wolverine Center’s Department of Child Welfare Licensing
Consultant met with Administrator 1 on 06/26/2023. The following
was discussed.
• Educate local urgent care and emergency room department
about Wolverine Center’s shelter program.
• Request local urgent care and emergency room
department to provide guidance on when medical
assessment and clearances are warranted.
• Establish urgent care and emergency room department
contact person.
• Notify urgent care and emergency room department
contact person prior to transporting a youth for an
evaluation.
• Continue daily clinical meetings and staff meetings
regarding youth requiring immediate, crucial interventions.
• Increase contact with Department of Health and Human
Service workers to review appropriateness of shelter
placement, individual youth strategies, and progress
towards appropriate, permanent placement.
• Continue hiring search for an additional therapist.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
